concern: As the title says, just looking to have the least amount of debt when I graduate. I'm heading into my senior year of high school in Venezuela with average GPA with 1320 SAT. My EFC is literally zero right now, but my parents agree I don't have a future in my country with my intended major in journalism.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm here to listen and help you explore any concerns or thoughts you might have. What's on your mind today?

I'm worried about figuring out how to handle college finances in a way that keeps my debt as low as possible. It's important to me to set up a solid plan for my future without the weight of loans holding me back.

It sounds like you're feeling anxious about the financial aspects of college and the impact it could have on your future. It's great that you're thinking about this early on and wanting to set yourself up for success. Have you looked into any resources or strategies for minimizing college debt?

I've started exploring scholarships, grants, and workstudy programs as ways to minimize college debt. I'm hoping these strategies will help me build a more secure future without the ongoing stress of loans.

It's fantastic that you're already taking steps to explore different options for financing your education. Scholarships, grants, and workstudy programs can certainly help reduce the amount you need to borrow. Have you considered speaking with a financial aid counselor at your school or a trusted financial advisor for additional guidance and support?

I've considered reaching out to a financial aid counselor at my school for more guidance on minimizing debt, but I haven't done so yet as I'm prioritizing exploring scholarships and grants first. This step feels important to ensure I build a stable financial plan for my future without relying heavily on loans.

It's great that you're prioritizing scholarships and grants, as they can significantly reduce your financial burden. At the same time, don't hesitate to reach out to a financial aid counselor sooner rather than laterthey can offer valuable insights and resources that you might not be aware of. Remember, it's all about being proactive and taking advantage of every opportunity to minimize your debt.

I appreciate your advice on reaching out to a financial aid counselor, as I'm eager to explore all options for support. Taking this step will help me stay proactive in minimizing my college debt and securing a more stable future.

Absolutely, staying proactive is key. Now, to help you get started, have you set a specific date or deadline for reaching out to a financial aid counselor? This can help ensure that you don't delay this important step.

I haven't set a specific date yet for reaching out to a financial aid counselor, as I'm still prioritizing my scholarship applications. I plan to establish a deadline soon to stay proactive and keep my debt as low as possible for a secure future.

It's wonderful that you're focusing on scholarships first. To stay on track, consider setting a deadline for contacting a financial aid counselor within the next 23 weeks. This way, you'll have a clear timeline to work towards and won't risk missing out on valuable guidance.

I appreciate your suggestion to set a deadline for contacting a financial aid counselor within the next 23 weeks, as it aligns with my goal of staying proactive. I'll make sure to establish that timeline soon to help minimize my college debt and secure a more stable future.
